cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.p: THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: Mr. George Vaysaie'slatest essay on Mustapha Pasha Kamel merits the attention of our readers—under the title of "Toujours Lui" the witty editor of "Le Journal du Caire" writes :

"Henceforth self-deception is useless. The situation is grave. It is hopeless bo imitate the .ostrich, hiding its head to get rid of the danger. Facts are facts. All yesterday the illustrious Karamel printed it—if Lord Cromer resigned it was because Karamel formally demanded his resignation. Wo can now realise what new light has dawned on the horizon and of what immense importance is the political revelation that it lias disclosed.

Our duty jvas plain-^to fly to the veritable Viceroy of Egypt and to attempt to obtain from him some precise indications of the meaning and the "dessous" of an event that has aatotfishejd the universe.

To tell the truth we felt a certain uneasiness as to our reception by the eminent patriot But knowing his perpe devotion to the National cause we belie - t that he could silence the claims of personal hostility in consideration of the interests of his Nilotic fatherland. We were right! With his habitual courtesy he deigned to open the door of the private, cabinet* that will henceforth be historical, where, he works to make history, and offering his hand with a gesture, the amplitude and dignity of which ' roused the admiration of all beholders, monounced these decisive word*, "Karamel will not remember the wrongs inflicted on Mustapha/'We entered.

The historic chamber presents nothing re- markable to the first glance. Its sole decoration , consists of the photographs with which it'i i walls are papered, but on attentive examination ( their interest and immense suggestiveness is revealed. Behold the official series of the ''Acta Dei per Karamelum'' ! History will obtain therefrom documentary evidence of immeasurable value. There you may see l — The Annunciation.
1/ 2.—Manifestation of the Angel Gabriel on the Mokattams.
3.— The reincarnation or the miracle of the
double mother. Adam gives his blessing to his namesake who is destined to re-create the human race

4.— The Al-Loti-ment where the guide of the nations is seen subdividing himself like a simple founder's share between the West, represented by an- illustrious academician of the East in the guise of sundry golden jays with human feces who represent subscribers to the multiple and already glorious Standards.
5 — The Flight ont of Egypt—a prophetic

vision—on a spavined ass at whose bridle tugs one, Farid, the great agitator traverses the desert of El Arish. Above him hovers an angel bearing a puppet In the background a group of shawishes at the double with "knees up".

div.p: El Serghani's case came before the Mousky Summary Court yesterday. The Court heard the evidence of Ali Bey Elghazar, Mohamed Eff. Hibeche, Mahmoud Bey Abdel Gaffar, Abdel Ghani Himejd, Abdel Hamid Eff. Soliman and Messrs. Moore, 'and Finlaison The Court then adjourned.

div.head: Cairo Cab Strike.
div.p: The cab strike at Cairo is over, the men returning to work this morning. The main ground for the strike was the new regulations, whereby they were liable to imprisonment for cruelty to their horses. The cabmen became somewhat obstreperous last 'night and were guilty of several assaults,

div.head: A Discovery.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-A few days ago a huge quantity of arms and ammunition were discovered at Tyneside, the division represented by Mr. J. M. Robertson, the champion of the Egyptian Nationalist. It is presumed that they were for export abroad to assist a revolutionary movement. I do not draw any conclusions. I merely state what is to be read in the home newspapers."

div.head: The Albrecht Affalr.
div.p: The Mixed Court of Appeal have reduced the damages awarded against the State Railway to Madame Albrecht. Doubtless it will be remembered that some two years ago M. Albrecht an avocat of Cairo fell out of a train through the door not being properly fastened and was killed. His widow Mme Albrecht sued the Railway Administration in the Mixed Tribunal of first instance and was awarded L.E 10,000 damages. She however did not think it enough and appealed. The Court of Appeal, however, confirmed the judgement of the Mixed Court but reduced the damages to L.E. 7,400.

div.head: 'The Matarieh Fire,
div.p: The following telegram was received at the Ministry of the Interior yesterday froni the moudir of Dakahlieh :-"The fire was extinguished the day before yesterday evening. About 1,500 houses have been burnt down, representing two-thirds of the town. The fames were greatly helped by the strong wind and by stacks of straw and dry cotton sticks which covered the roofs of the houses Four persons have perished and nearly all the population are without shelter and food The material losses are considerable and the state of the people is deplorable. Please send us as soon as possible 100 tents and 5,000 okes of biscuits."

div.head: Fire-at Kom el Dik.
div.p: Yesterday evening about 6 o'clock a fire broke out in the married quarters of the British garrison åt Kom el Dik which were completely destroyed, the six rooms of which the quarter consisted being burnt to the ground. The fire was noticed by Superinten dent Waller from the fire station, who immewiately called out the brigade and hurried to the scene, to find that four rooms had already gone. A quarter of an hour was passed before any water conld be got, on account of the distance of the nearest hydrants. The force, of the water, too, was feeble, the height to which it had to be taken being considerable. It appears that the fire was caused by the bursting of an oil cooking stove.

div.head: A New Levant Line.
div.p: It is said at Budapest that the negotiations! of the German companies for the creation of a new Hungarian-Levant líne have ended in failure, and that Herr Pilis, of the Norddeutscher-Lloyd, who was treating, is reported to have tendered his resignation. On the other hand, the company announces that it has raised its American tariff by 10s. to £15, which is taken to signify an abandonment of the tariff war. As the creation of the Hungarian-Levant line was. the real basis of the whole project for transfefring the emigration business from the Cunard Steamship Company to local and Gerinan management, it is probable that if the pourparlers have failed, the transatlantic traffic from Fiume may yet be left to the Crnard...

div.head: A suggestion for Egyptian Railways.
div.p: The american western railroads have just added a new and important member to their publicity department which might will be unitated by the Egyptian Railway Administration. For want of a better official title, he is known as "General Hublic." It is his sole business, by constant travel over his own com pany's road and other systems and making personal observations, to keep his vicepresident informed as to the needs of the public and the manner in which the company is meeting them. "General Public" is not intended to be a "igpotter," but is to be the medium through whom the management of the line hopes to keep in closer touch with the great body of its clients So he travels in the day.coaches, buys his tickets in the booking office along with the crowd, notes how the agents answer the inquiries of perplexed travellers regarding time, connections, and luggage, and draws, comparisons regarding the service furnished by the differert lines,

div.head:
THE BRITISH AGENCY.
NO CHANGES IN STAFF.
div.p: It is understood that Sir Eldon Gorst will not take any staffout with him to Egypt, but will assume charge of the British Agency at Cairo with the staff as fully equipped as under Lord Croiner's régime. | Sir Eldon Gorst will be accompanied on his journey ont to Egypt by Mr. Ronald Graham, of the Foreign Office, who is to succeed Mr. Findlay as first Secretary at the British Agency.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA-PIRAEUS.
THE FUTURE ROUTE TO EUROPE.
div.p: The Piraeus will in 1909 be the port par excellance for those who want to travel by the shortest sea bute between Egypt and Europe. The Greek Railway Company, which is a combination of the Eastern Railway Construction Syndicate with the Société des Batignolles has constructed about 194 kilometres (1204 miles) up to the Bralo tunnel and two branch lines to Lamia and Chalcis--46 kilometres (28] miles). These sections are actually open for traffic. The line will now be carried to Larissa, or the Turkish frontier---347 kilometres (195} miles)--and continued on Ottoman territory along the Tempe Valley for a distance of 46 kilometres (28} miles). The completion of this line-which it is expected will take place in 1909---will bring all Euro. pean railways (by means of the Belgrade to Salonika-junction line) in direct communica 'tion with the Piræus, which port may then

afford a point of departure for Egypt, India, and the East generally. So much importance is laid upon that fact that it has been provided that in case the concession for the extension on Turkish ground cannot be obtained, the constructing company will construct a branch line to Platamon, and will maintain a daily steamer connexion with Salonika in return for an annual guarantee of £,4,000.

div.head: FORWARDING AGENTS.
div.p: The letter which appeared in the February journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt from: Mr. A.G M. Dickson, the SubGovernor of the National Bank of Egypt, on the subject of his experience with forwarding agents, has called forth certain protests from firms engaged in this line of business.
As a matter of possible interest, especially with regard to the remarks re primage, this journal gives the following extract from one of the protests in question made by a forwarding agent.
"We conduct our business in a simple and "perhaps old fashioned manner) but we closely "conpare all measurements sent in by the "shipbrokers with those given to us by the "suppliers of the goods.
"When the shipping companies make us no "allowance of the primage, we charge a "shipping commission of 5 %, but it is seldom
" that companies decline to allow us ą, portion "" of the primage charged-in either case all
"other rebates and deluctions that we can "obtain are allowed by us to our clients in "full

"In the case of small shipments, such as one " or two packages which are carried at a mini-"mom freight, we make a charge for commis."sion of say 5/; or thereabouts, in full. " Customs entry we have a fixed charge of 2/6, "and Bills of Larling (3 stamped and 1 uns"tamped) 2/-.
"We enclose for your information a form of "the account of charges we always render, and " which, you will see, gives fall details of the "actual items of disbursements made by us."
The firm is quite correct in saying that they supply full details of all charges for an examin*ation of their blank invoices shows that

provision has been made for almost every conceivable item, even down to postages. Although it is only fair to say the firm state they very seldom charge postages, it seems to us that, even with this concession, there is not much relief for the man who only ships a small package, since, without freight and cartage, he starts with a minimuni charge of 9/6 "or thereabouts." The system may be simple and old fashioned, but it has the appearance of being a paying one.

div.head: EGYPT'S COMMERCE.
div.p: During last month the total value of goods imported into Egypt amounted to L.E. 2,159,791 as compared with L.E. 1,860,912 in March 1906, while the exports totalled L.E. 2,322,886 as against L.E. 2,103,119 in the coresponding month of last year. Between January 1 and March 31 the import values amounted to L.E 6,155,042 (an increase of L E. 893,351 over last year) and the exports to L.E. 8,977,890, which was an increase of L.E. 1,536,113. Of the March imports the value of L.E. 694,546 came from Great Britain, L.E. 285,329 from France, L.E. 202,962 from Turkey, L.E. 187,569 from Austria-Hungary, L.E. 134,362 from British possessions in the Far East, L.E. 122,508 from Italy, L.E. 110,441 from Belgium, and L.E. 105,306 from Germany, while, taking these countries in the same order, the exports were L.E. 1,081,661, L.E. 149,156, L.E. 26,036, L.E. 127,623, LE. 11,793, L.E. 84,773, L.E. 21,318, and L.E. 223,547,

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION. THE ALEXANDRIA MEMORIAL. YEHIA PASHA'S PROTEST.
div.p: The meeting of the special committee, nominated by the Alexandria Municipal Commission in or to decide as to the means of perpetuating Lord Cromer's memory, assembled yesterday afternoon at 6 o'clock, Dr. Schiess Pasha in the chair, Great interest was manifested as to whether Ahmed Yehia Pasha, who had been chosen specially as representative of the natives on this committee, would put in an appearance. The Pasha, however, remained true to his nationalist convictions as a follower of Mustapha Pasha Kamel And, instead of putting in an appearance, sent a letter of protest against the action of the Alexandria Municipality in forming a committee in order to perpetuate Lord Cromer's memory! It is rumoured that the Pasha has received strong support in the attitude which he has taken ap in this matter from certain quarters. Whether this report be true or not cannot be proved, but it will be worth while observing if the Pasha or his other native" colleagues on the Municipal Commission are! the recipients of any marks of favour, such as natives in their position esteem. The attitude of Yehia Pasha and of the Native Municipal Commission has been specially remarked in view of the fact that a number of wellknown natives, including members of the Legislative Council, have decided to join the Committee at Cairo. S

Yehia Pasha was, it should be remembered, one of the leading spirits in that remarkable fiasco of a few years ago-the memorial on the occasion of the Mohamed Aly centenary. He initiated the subscription' to the memory of the founder of the Khedivial Dynasty, but nobody ever asked for the money,

The Committee have decided to perpetuate Lord Cromer's name in Alexandria by bestow ing it on one of the new parks and to call the square in front of the site of the new theatre near the Rosetta Gate "Lord Cromer's Square." It was decided that the most suitable memorial would be the foundation of a satatorium for persons afflicted with tuberculosis. This institution would be ran in connection with the Anti-Tuberculosis League, which is doing such good work in Alexandria to combat the ravages of this disease. It will be of advantage to all classes of the population, for at the present time owing to no such institution existing at Alexandria, & great deal of preventable contagion caused by persons afflicted with this malady, who have no place of the kind to resort to. It was decided to submit this proposal to Lord Cromer. On the receipt of his Lordship's reply, it will be submitted to the general committee, which will meet on Sunday.

Another proposition was made at yesterday's I meeting in favour of the institution of a hospital for sick children. But this scheme was not received with favour, owing to the notorious disposition of the native's to prevent their children going to hospital at any cost. Moreover the European colonies in Alexandria have institutions of this sort and it was consequently considered that such a hospital would not fulfil a public need in yny degree as much as a sanatorium for tuberculous patients.

An official Committee has been formed in Cairo under the presidency of Moustafa Pasha Fehmy, president of the Council of Ministers, of all the ministers, advisers, members of the Diplomatic Corps, members of the Legislative Council and several native notables

In consequence of the state of Lord Cromer's health the proposal of a banquet was rejected and it was decided to present an address to Lord Cromer at a mass meeting to be held at the Abbas theatre. Other projects are under consideration.
WALKER & MEIMARACHI LIMITED.

An informal meeting of shareholders of this company was held at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, yesterday afternoon, when some 90,000 shares were represented. The chairman of the company briefly explained the impossible posi- ! tion which has arisen owing to divergence of views between the members of the board in - London and Cairo respectively. Mr. Bigiavi

expressed the opinion that in view of the high and constantly increasing rent paid by the company for its present insufficient premises, the desirability of obtaining increased accom_ modation in one central building, and the excellent situation of the company's land, the interests of the company could best be served by the erection of a sufficient building on the Sharia Manakh land. | The meeting was then asked to express an opinion whether or not it was in favour of adopting this course ; and whether or not it was in favour of the resolutions to be voted on at the extraordinary general meeting to be held. Votes in favour of keeping and building on the land, and in favour of the proposed resolutions were passed unanimously with the exception of Messrs. George and John Walker, who voted against the motions. I n

Mr. Bigiavi and other shareholders objected to shareholders being asked to deposit their shares in the Anglo-Egyptian Bank only on the ground that this would cause a serious disorganisation of the financial arrangements of shareholders. The chairman, explained that some time ago the board passed a resolution authorising shareholders to depoxit in several of the leading banks in Cairo; that it was the suggestion of the London directors that shares should be deposited in one bank only, but that the wishes of shareholders would no doubt be net.

The chafrman informed the meeting that the extraordinary general meeting would be held on the 6th May next, and that if the resolu. tions were thrown out, the directors in Egypt would hand in their resignations,

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT. LORD CROMERS'S SUCCESSOR. SIR ELDON GORST'S POWERS.
div.p: London, Friday. In the House of Commons last night the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was asked whether the status and power of Sir Eldon Gorst, as the British Diplomatic Agent and Consul General at Cairo, would be identical with that wielded by Lord Cromer. Sir Edward Grey in reply declared that Sir Eldon's position and powers would be identical with those of his predecessor.
THE BAHR-EL-GHAZAL.

Mr. H. P. Pease asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs yesterday week whether he had any official information showing that Congo Free State troops were still occupying four stations in the Bahr-el-Ghazal, and that the Lado enclave was occupied by a force of 1,800 men; and if so, whether he could explain the reasons which induced the Congo Free State Administaation to maintain so large a military force within striking distance of British territory. .

Mr. Runciman : Mr. Pease understands that telegraphic instructions have now been sent to the Congolese Commandant at Lado ordering the evacuation of all posts in Meridi. . * MR. ROBERTSON'S QUESTIONS.
The following questions were asked by Mr. Robertson on last Tuesday. .
In each case Şir Edward Grey answered that i he had no information to give on the subject.
Whether Stanton Bey had applied the term bakshish to the price paid for expropriated land at Khartum ;
Whether the inhabitants of Khartoum requesting thecreation of girls schools had been referr- i ed to the Protestant missionary schools ;
Whether the Sudanese Government paid arbitrary prices for expropriated lands, reselling the half ayah of land at fifteen pounds a feddan when the price paid for it bad only been two pounds.
Whether the confiscated Wakf lands could not be dedicated to educational purposes. I
The following is the full text of questions asked by Mr. J.M. Robertson in Parliament on the 11th inst of which a summary has already been given :---

Mr. J. M. Robertson (Northumberland, Tyneside) asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs, whether he was aware that the penalties inficted on landholders in Egypt for infractions ofrules, take the form of withdrawal of irrigation water supply for a given number of days; whether he could state the number of cases in which such penalties were inflicted during the past year ; and whether, seeing that such penalties were inexpedient, as having the effect of seriously checking agricultural production he would instruct the British Agent at. Cairo to advise the substitution of fines and other penalties of a less economically injurious character.

Sir E. Grey. I have no information on this subject. I do not consider it advisable to instruct the British Agent to interfere more than is necessary in matters of administrative detail. · Mr J. M. Robertson --Can we have any definition of the right hon. gentleman's idea of his powers of intervention ? * Sir E. Grey.-It is exceedingly difficult to give definitions. I can say the general policy is to interfere as little as possible if we are sure we have good men in charge. (Cheers).

Mr. John Robertson :-To ask the Secretary'' of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he is aware that in the British Consular Service in China and Japan, promotion depends largely upon proficiency in the native language; whether three years' study is prescribed, with at least three examinations, and whether he will take steps to secure that in Egypt, where the British civil servants are so largely engaged in administrative duties a similar standard of proficiency in the native language shall be established for them ,

Sir Edward Grey :- Promotion in the British Consular Service in China and Japan no doubt depends greatly on proficiency in the native language. I have no reason to believe that this is not also the case in the Egyptian Civil Service. But Englishmen in the service of the Khedive are subject to regulations laid down by the Government, and not by that of His Majesty. It is, however, the case that the native language is one of the qualifications for entry into the Egyptian Service.

RAS EL TIN SCHOOL
SPORTS AND GYMNASTICS.
div.p: The annual sports of the Ras el Tin Government School were held yesterday afternoon, when there was a goodly number of interested spectators. Before the commencement of the sports a football match of ten minutes each way was played between teams of the 4th year primary a section and the 2nd year secondary E section The match was very well and evenly contested, considerable skill being shown by both sides. In the first half the primary team secured two goals, and as neither side scored in the second half, the game ended at 2-nil. The horizontal bar display was very fairly gone through and the boys showed good progress. One of the best displays of the afternoon was the club drill, which included wand exercises and Swedish extension movements. This display was given by a team of 40 who went through the various exercises in a very smart manner and all through showed most creditable precision and neatness. Prior to the sports there was a competition on Wednesday afternoon between the primary and secondary sections, in which the former won by two points--68-66 out of a possible 90. The tugof-war with a 15 ft. rope between teams of ten boys from the 2nd year secondary E section and the 3rd year secondary E section was very evenly pulled, the former winning by 2 pulls to 1 after three good struggles. The display on the parallel bars was most excellent and the boys showed quite exceptional ability in the most difficult exercises ; the standard, indeed, was fully equally to that of any European schools. This display was concluded by the formation of a pyramid by the boys, which was greatly appreciated by the spectators. Vaulting the horse was also very smartly performed, the boys showing great agility and confidence and not a single stumble being made. This was the last event of the afternoon and the competitors were paraded round the grounds and drawn up in line before the Governor, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, for the presentation of prizes, which included those won at the general Government Sports held at Cairo and the Alexandria Amateur Athletic Club Sports in events open to natives. The Ras elTin school, whose standard of excellence is of the highest order, secured at Cairo the greatest number of prizes won by any one school and all the open events in the Ibrahimieh sports. Those won at Cairo were the 1st in the quarter mile and 100 yards races and the 2nd in the high jump and hurdles. The best gymnast of the afternoon proved to be Halim Fahmi who for the second year 'in succession won the first prize for gymnastics, the second and third prizes going to Hussein el Hakim and Amin Mohyi, respectively. The club drill was won by the primary section and the company drill by No. 3 company. For the purpose of general parade the school is divided into five companies. The competition is always regarded as one of the greatest events and great enthusiasm is shown by all the boys in competiting; the results of their physical training and the efficiency of the boys reflects great

credit on their trainer, Ibrahiin Effendi Khalil. - After the prizes had been distributed by Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, three times "Effendimiz chok Yasha" was given and the company dispersed. During the afternoon Ismail Bey Hassanein; director of the school, was "at home" and tea was served. The organisation of the sports was in the hands of Mr. Clark Shaw, and the judge was Mr. W.H. Brockway, superintendent of drill and gymnastics to the Ministry of Education. Great help was rendered by Mulazim Hassan Effendi Moustafa, who Assisted in the superintendence of the pupils during the sports.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Flavian sailed from Malta yesterday evening (Thursday) for Mizrata and Alexandria.
The S.S. Alexandria sailed yesterday evening for Poti in ballast.
The Papayanni liner City of Cambridge, leaving on Saturday the 20th inst for Liverpool, via Malta, bas ample first class accomodation.
The Ss. City of Perth, of the Westcott Laurance Line of London, left Malta yesterday and is due here via Tripoli next Toesday, the 23rd, with general merchandise from Antwerp and London. |

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Errington, Lord Cromer's eldest son arrived in Cairo on Wednesday.
Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, who left Alexandria yesterday for Mariout and Mersa Matrouh, will be back on Monday or Tuesday next.
Mr. Theotokis, the Greek deputy and brother of the Greek Prime Minister, arrived at Alexandria from Port Said yesterday and will embark for the Piraeus in a few days.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
M. FERAUDY IN CAIRO.
div.p: "Brichanteau," given on Monday night, is by M. de Feraudy himself. It is a play on which one hesitates to pronounce. Amusing and pathetic in turns, rising eventually to a real height and dignity in the last act, it should be a great play, but somehow one feels that more might have been made of the whole, that the presentment of the old "Cabotin," the superior strolling player to whom all life is a stage, and all the stage and reality of life might be very wonderful and convincing ; perhaps the sense of a certain detachment-hardly incoherencein the development and even in the scenes, is the prevailing note, and reason for the impression produced. The play opens with a rehearsal, at which Brichanteau is in fine form : it is his farewell to the provinces. At the end enters Mlle Fanchette Claret, anxious for a stagecareer. He hears her recitations and asks her to see him the next day. She appears duly (the 2nd act) but thinks him hopelessly unreal and theatrical. In the next 'act she reappears, successful in Paris, married to Gaston Murat, happy in their suburban house. Enter Brichanteau bearing swords, in deadly stage-earnest. He declares his love, has a duel with Murat, is scratohed, ard in one final scene with Fanchette attempts to interpret his real mental attitude towards her, the stage, and his own life, but, poor man, he hardly knows it himself. The realisation, bitter and only too clear, comes in the last act. He is no longer the favorite of the provinces, but only an old broken down invalid, kept alive in his tiny cottage on a meagre income given him by an indulgent admirer. But he has. learnt what life in it really is from the humble villagers, and he now knows how he should, and could, play it on the stage. Fanchette comes to see him ; in her hand she has the book of the part she is to create in Paris, she listens to his talk, now only too full of reality and know| ledge, and asks him to show her how to interpret her part. He does so, he simulates the nervous excitement, the stifled cry, 'and the collapse - to 'perfection and more than perfection, for his worn out heart fails, and he |dies there and then. It is enough to say of M.. de Feraudy that he was Brichanteau throughout, neither more nor less, rollicking, wildly amorous, then theatrically defiant, and at last, saddened, experienced, regretful, awakening one instant to his lost enthusiasms ard his art. 1 | The other parts are slight enough, and all the actors were quite adequate. M. Goornac was good as the constant grumbler who at last has to ask his old friend for a fivepound note. Sévérin as Murat was better than before, and more natural, and Mlle Van Doren was excel | lent as Débutante and then as the successful

but disillusionized actress. But that disI proportion to which I have alluded rather overshadowed and minimized the parts as well as the piece itself. Still it was a novel and | distinctly interesting performance. I must (mention the curious interlude of Lord and Lady Hartson. Lord Hartson made quitea creditable attempt at the English language and accent but he should not pronounce Lady Maud's name as "Mode"! still he is represented as speaking French well, and so perhaps it was justifiable.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES
div.p: TRAMWAYS DALEXANDRIE

L'exercice écoulé se solde avec des bénéfices nets s'élèvent à la somme de fr.l,4I2,611 qui est ainsi repartie: fr.386,254, pour le service de l'emprunt des obligations, fr. 103,694 fonds'de renouvellement,fr. 9,200 réserve pour impôts de r exercice, f r. 46,67 3 reserve statu tai re,fr. 480,000 premier dividende de 6 francs aux actions privilégiées, fr.38.779 Conseil (l'Administration, fr.77,557, à titre de 2ème dividende aux ne tions privilégiées et 271.462 aux actions de dividende.
Les actions privilégiées toucheront ainsi fr.7 et les actions de Dividende fr,8,20 par titre.

Ces chiffres sont asser. éloquents et démontrent le progrès constant de l'exploitation, qui, prendra un essor plus grand lorsque la Société pourra exploiter toutes les nouvelles lignes projetées, particulièrement celle du jardin Nouzha, sur le Canal Mahmoudieh, aux quartiers de RpselTin et Abou-el-Abbas en passant par les nouveaux quais.
Le Conseil étudie le moyen le plus économique de se procurer les fonds nécessaires pour tous les travaux des nouvelles lignes projetées.

L'année dernière la Société avait été saisie, par un groupe d'environ 50 mille porteurs d'actions privilégiées et dividendes, d'un projet d'unification des deux catégories de titres, par un capital unique d'actions ordinaires.
Depuis le décés du regretté administrateur M. Glymenopoulo, plusieurs porteurs importants ayant déclaré formellement ne vouloir plus l'unification, le projet a dft être abandonné.
Le Conseil d'Administration a pourvu à la vacance laissé par fèu Glymenopoulo en nommant comme administrateur, son lieau-fils, M. John Chini.
CAISSE HYPOTHECAIRE D'EGYPTE,

C'est hier que s'est réunie au siège social, à Bruxelles, l'Assemblée générale des actionnaires de la Caisse Hypothécaire d'Egypte, pour l'examen des comptes annuels et la fixation du dividende à distribuer. Nous savons d'ores et déjà par les journaux belges que le Conseil proposera 9 fr 75 pour les actions ordinaires correspondant à 7,80 0/0 du capital versé nt 20 francs pour les parts de fondateurs.
Pour les comptes de l'exercice 1906, clôturé le 31 décembre dernier, le projet de bilan que nous avons sous les yeux nous en fait connaître les principaux chapitres.
Au nombre de ceux-ci, il convient de citer :

1° Les placements effectués, se subdivisant' en deux classes : les prêts hypothécaires pour son propre compte, qui s'élevaient à 21,440,821 francs, et ceux pour compte de tiers à 8,627,651 francs ; ensemble : 30,068,472 francs.
2° Les obligations, dont le nombre total créé a été de 70,000, donnant un total de 35 millions de francs, et le nombre restant à émettre de 11,614 pour un montant dé
6.807.0 francs, accusant ainsi pour les titres placés 68,3âC et pour leur valeur nominale
29.193.0 francs.
La partie la plus intéressante se rapporte aux comptes réserves et amortissement spécial qui, pour nous, doivent se confondre et dont le montant total s'élève déjà à 722,605 francs.
C'est urt chiffre considérable par rapport à l'existence de la Société, qui remonte à trois ans seulement, et au montant versé de son capital, 2,500^000 francs formant ainsi près do 29% de celui-ci.

Rapportés à la prime de remboursement des obligations placées, les 722,605 francs représen feraient un peu plus de 22%. A la parfaite sécurité des prêts effectués par cet établissement, cette proportion ajouterait donc un appoint très sensible.

Les recettes de tous ordres de l'exercice so sont élevées à 1,764,372 francs, sur lesquels le service des obligations, les frais généraux et les amortissements ont absorbé 1,419,429 francs, laissant comme bénéfice net 344,943 francs.

Par rapport à 1» distribution proposée parle Conseil pour le dividende, cette somme lais serait un écart très élevé. Il est probable que le surplus, déduction faite de la part de lu réserve statutaire et du tantième des ad ministrateurs. aura été employé en amortisse ments.

Voilà, en résumé, des résultats fort satis faisants, qui permettent de dire que les titres de cette Société semblent des placements réimt nérateurs. En effet, les 9 fr. 75 du coupon représenteraient, par rapport au cours actuel en Bourse, près de 6%, ce qui est joli pour un titre de placement auasi sûr.
Cirotilairô H. De Vries et Boutigny

div.p: The Budget Bhews an available surplus for 1907/8 £3,233,000 No diminution in taxation is proposed but a rebate of three pence will be allowed upon earned incomes when the total income does not exceed £2,000. Death duties will be re-adjusted increasing the taxation on estates of over £150,000. £1,500,000 is to be invested this year in a sinking fund, earmarked next year for an old age pension fund. The budget surplus for 1906 07 shews an amount of £5,399,000 whidh will be devoted to the reduction of debt. The surplus is due mainly to estate and coal duties. The reduction of the tea duty has lead to the consumption of an ad litional £4,500,000 worth. The taxation on alcohol exceeded the estimate >y- £150,000. The estimated expenditure of 1907/08 amounts to £140,757,000 and the revene, with the existing taxation, to £144,190,000. Necessitous schools require £200,000 and the available surplus amounts to £3,233,000. Mr. Asquith insists on the necessity of reinstating and improving the national credit. A further reduction in debt was a paramount necessity, but beyond that was the necessity for social reform. The Government intended before next session to lay the foundation of a system of old age pensiohs. (Reuter)

div.head:
ROYAL MEETING AT GAETA.
KING LEAVES FOR NAPLES.

div.p: King Edward and^Queen Alexandra hav arrived at Gaeta : King Victor Emmanuel and Signor Tittoni went on board their ÿacht : the crowd ashore cheered.

King Edward met King Victor Emmanuel on the gangway : the monarchs warndy embraced. King Edward afterwards conversed with Signor Tittoni and others. His Majesty returned the visit on board King Victor Em * manuel'B yacht^here he 'lunched. No toasts
The English sovereigns have sailed and King Victor Emmanuel has returned to Rome.
A semi-official note issued here declares the meeting as private and quite unpolitical.
(Reuter)
Kings Victor Emmanuel and Edward have exchanged cordial * visits to each others yachts.

They lunched on board the Trinacria ; nc toasts were given. The meeting, although not political, is considered as a guarantee of peace a,nd a strengthening of Ahglo-Italian friendship. The English Sovereigns have left for Naples privately and King Victor Emmanuel has returned to Rome. * ( Havas)

The German Government has formally disavowed all responsibility for yesterday's article in the "Koelnische Zeitung" which sharply criticized King Edward's proceedings in the Mediterranean and notably his visit to Gaeta! The English papers,' however, have begun warmly retorting. Tfiey ascribe the criticisms to enmity which is incapable of viewing the most innocent acts of the Sovereign rationally (Reuter)
Four shots were fired yesteiday evening at the Persian engineer Mirza Abbas Chaniz, whilst passing through the town en mi Persia. His condition is serious. (Reuter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET-
div.p: Tho Money Market.

As wè predicted in our article a week ago, the money market has shown continuous ease, the best financial circles it is considered certain thatthis ease will be maintainedforsome considerable period. The action of the Bank directors in reducing their rate by only $ per cent, is admitted to be a wise one, although for the moment the Bank is much above the open market as when the rate was 5 per cent Indeed, the drop in discount has been fully 1 per cent Nevertheless, a policy of caution is best.

The Bank is strengthening its position, and aconsiderablgjrfnouut of public money isbeing dispersed in the purchase of Consols by the Government. This security has not however, responded very much to the improved conditions, and this chiefly owing to the impending large issues ofL. C. C. and other municipal loans, which will' tap the supply of money available for gilt edged securities. On the whole, however, the tone is altogether more healthy than for a lortg time past.

The Bank return, while not quite coming up to expectations, is very satisfactory, showing as it does an increase in the reserve of : £1,274,000 to £25,185,000. The stock of bullion is higher by £l'l 16,000, of which {£998,000 pame from abroad, while the note | circulation shows a contraction of £158,000.

Public deposits are lower by £4,393,000 owing I to Government disbursements. The ratio of reserve to liabilities is 2} per cent. higher at i43} per cent It is interesting to note that i since January 17, when the Bank rate was reduced to 5 per cent, the reserve has been increased by more than £2,600,000.
The Stock Market».

Although it woilld not be correct to say that the present condition of things on the Stock Exchange reveals a substantial improvement in the volume of busiuess—rather, the past two or three days have been characterised by a languid tone—it is nevertheless
Foreign Bond».
The strength of international bonds has .been a feature of the foreign market this week.
have received considerable support
inactive, and with the exception of slight falls . in North Western, North Eastern, South West Def. and North British Ord.' 'prices are well- maintained.
Egyptian». j p

The Egyptian market has been quiet, but t Ij closes1 with a much better tone. Thé effect of1 ' Lord Cromer's resignation on shares has been very slight One reason for this is that the Alexahdria Bourse being closed to-day dealers have been unable to obtain a correct impression as to how the news has been received.in Egypt Another reason is that the resignation has not created an uneasy feeling, as it is believed that Lord Cromer's work and policy will be ably maintained by his successor.

National Bank of Egypt, after being a firm market at 26} buyers, close easier at 25|:|, while Agricultural Bank are also down to 8f-9 The Preference are 9}-J. Agricultural Bank Debentures have been a bad market with a good many small sellers about, the price being quite nominal at 86-8. Delta Preference Bearer have changed hands at 10}, bat eloee 10 3-11}, and Delta Land and Investment at 3}, but there are sellers of the latter at this price. United Egyptian Lands are dull again at about par, and Egyptian Estates at 1 |-|. Union Foncière are better at 5|-| ex. div. after being flat at 4|-f . Land Bank of Egypt 8}-f Anglo-Egyptian Bank

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: K. S. C.
POLO MATCH.
A polo match "Married versus Single" was played at Ghezirehon Taesday the 16th inst, and although neither side was quite representative the game was very good and interesting.
Tho Married—who were naturally more accustomed to discipline—showed the better combination, and won by 6 goals to 4.
Teams as follows.
Married Single
Mr. Murray I. Capt Sterling I
Mr. Jervis Smith II. Mr. Fuller-Mait-
[landll
Major Pereira III. Mr. BentinckllL
Capt Hon. C. Monck (back) Mr. Gibbs (back)

FIRST CHUKKER.—Mr. Murray with an excellent long shot scored first goal for the "Married," then Capt Sterling for the "Single" with a good back hander brought the score level, and shortly afterwards the "Single" scored another. Score single 2, married 1.
SECOND CHUKKER—"Single" score again- making 3 to 1 in theit favour. But the Married then notched another point and quickly followed this up with a third—bringing the soore to
3 all
THIRD CHUKKER.—Married scored again from an excellent run up the ground, the "Single" onoe more brought the game level to
4 all.
FOURTH CHUKKER.—The Married, evidently anticipating trouble if they were defeated, made great efforts and quickly scored 2 more goals thus winning a fast and interesting match by 2 goals.

KHARTOUM GOLF CLUB.
The usual monthly competition of the Khartoum Golf Club was held on Tuesday April 2nd and resulted in -a tie between. Major E V. Turner and Capt R. J Done There were sixteen competitors SCORES.
Major E. V. Turner 48 - 6 = 42 \ Capt R J. Done 48 — 6 = 42 J
Mr. J. R Bayes 52 — 7 = 43
„ M. Fleming 49 — 4 = 45
„ J. G. Currie 50 — 5 == 45
„ H P. Hewins 55 — 10 = 45
Major-General Sir F. R. Wingate 54 — 8 = 46 Archd. L. H. Gwynne 50 — 3 = 47 Capt H. D. Pearson 56 — 9 = 47 All other competitors either made no returns or returned scores over 50 nett.
The tie between Major Turner and Capt Done was played off on Thursday the 4th inst, vflien Capt Done woft with the score of 46 — 6 = 40.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: AVIS

Messieurs les Actionnaires de là National Bank of Egypt, sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le samedi vingt Avril 1907 à 3.30 de l'après-midi, au Siège Social, au Caire, afin de délibérer sur la proposition suivante :
Augmentation du Capital Social et modification de l'article 10 des Statuts.

Tout actionnaire possédant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part à l'Assemblée Générale à condition de déposer ses actions dans l'un des lieux ci-après désignés oi» il lui sera délivré one carte d'admissiôn :

En Egypte, cinq jours au moins avant le jour de la réunion,soit le 13 Avril Ru plus tard: au Siège Social, au Cairn ; à la Suocnrsale d'Alexandrie ; aux Agences de la Banque à Assiont, Assouan, Benha, Beni-Souef, Chebin- el-Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Keneh, Man- sourah, Minieh, Louxor, Port-Said, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, ot Mousky (Caire) et dans les Etablissements'de banque suivants du Caire et d'Alexandrie : Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Bank of Egypt, Banque d'Athènes, Banque Impériale Ottomane, Banque d'Orient Banque rie Saloni- que, Cassa di Seonto e di Risparmio, Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris, Crédit Lyonnais, Deutsche Orientbank A.G.

En Europe, au plus tard, le 11 Avril : à Paris et à Marseille, aux bureaux de la "Société Marseillaise;" en Italie, duns les bu reaux de la "Banca Commerciale ltaliana à Londres, à l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt 4 & 5. King William Street.
L'Assemblée pour pouvoir délibérer valablement devant réunir la moitié des actions émises, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont priés de faire le dépéri de toutes leurs actions.
Le Gouverneur F. T. ROWLATT.
Le Caire, le 16 Mars 1907. 29792-ll*-9
